editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Childrens Talke, ENGLISH & LATINE, divided into ſeveral Clauſes: Wherein the Propriety of both Languages is kept.
That Children by the help of their Mother-Tongue may more eaſily learn to diſcourſe in good Latine amongſt themſelves.
There are alſo Numbers ſet down betwixt both, which doe ſhew the place and naturall uſe of any Word or Phraſe.
By Charles Hoole Mr of Arts, L C. Oxon. Teacher of a Private Grammar-Schoole betwixt Goldſmiths-Alley in Red-croſs ſtrert and Maiden head Court in Alderſgate-ſtreet, LONDON.
M. Cord Lib. 3. Coll. 34. Latine it ſelf doth conſiſt rather in Ʋſe and Authority, then Reaſon or Rule.
LONDON, Printed for the Company of Stationers, 1659.
PUERILES CONFABULATIUNCULAE, ANGLO-LATINAE, in varias clauſulas diſtributae: Obſervato utriuſque Linguae idiomate.
Quò ſc. Colloquia ſat bene Latina faciliùs ope vernaculi pueri conterant.
Poſiti ſunt inſuper utriuſque confiniis Numeri, quibus uniuſcujuſque vocabuli vel Phraſeos indicatur locus & uſus genuinus.
A CAROLO HOOL A. Mro è Col. Lin. Oxon. Privatae Scholae Grammaticae Inſti • utore inter Aurifabrorum diverticulum in Rubrae Crucis, & aream Virginei Capitis in Alneae Portae vicis Apud Londinates.
M. Cord. Lib. 3. Col. 34. Ipſa Latinitas uſu & autoritate magis quàm ratione conſtat.

div.head: To his really reſpected good friends, Mr. Ioſeph and Mr. Humphrey Primate Citizens of London.
div.p:
YOur deſires are (worthy Sirs) to have your Sons gain a faculty of ſpeaking Latine, as well as Engliſh; a thing which I obſerve many parents wiſh for, and ſome School-maſters more ſtudiously labour after; but the many difficulties that attend the work (eſpecially in a Mort Language, and with Children not throughly grounded, many of whoſe Parents, being illiterate, or intending ſomthing elſe, doe not care, or afford any encouragement
to have their Sons brought up in a Scholar-like way) hath made moſt of our Profeſsion, either not at all to undertake the task, or not till a perfect knowledge be had of the Grammer Rules, which is very rare, (I had almoſt ſaid impoſſible) before diſcretion.

To helpe forward your good wiſhes herein, I have formerly furniſhed them with ſtore of words; and ſome neceſſary Rules, or directions, how to put them together in forme of Speech, imitating ever and anon the expreſſions of thoſe Authors, whereof they were then capable. And obſerving that Colloquies are moſt ſuitable to children, (who like nothing ſerious long) and excellently profitable to attaine ability of diſcourſe, by comparing Language with language: I have purpoſely tranſlated ſo many of the
choiceſt Books of them, and diſpoſed them in ſuch method, as may readilieſt enable young learners (as they paſs the Grammer Rules, and lower Authors) to write or ſpeake properly upon any occaſion, that ſo being acquainted with the Language aforehand, they may more cheerfully Proceed in Authors truly Claſsicall, and excerpt and note from thence ſuch Grammaticall, Rhetoricall, Morall, and other quaint paſſages, as themſelves are able to obſerve or their Maſters bid them minde.

And becauſe a man that keeps not the road, is likely many times to be left to go alone, and Children muſt be led along by an eaſier (though perhaps it be not a ſhorter) way then men may preſume to take. I make uſe of ſuch Books eſpecially, as are generally received in Grammer Schools; and have begun with Pueriles Confabulatiunculae, writ
heretofore (as is propable) in Dutch and Latine by Evaldus Gallus, and with us commonly taught in Latine onely, to young-ſmatterers in that tongue, becauſe it ſeems cheap and pleaſant.

This therefore at preſent, I beſeech you, be pleaſed to accept on your Sons behalfe, whom I thus ſtudy to benefit at a diſtance becauſe I am engaged to you by ſpeciall favours here, whereof I ought not to be backward to let the world take notice, however your ſelves account it enough to have done a courteſie.
And now the God of al goodneſs ſupply you and yours with meet gifts and graces to doe him ſervice: and increaſe your comforts here and herefter: Let me remaine.

closer.signed: Yours moſt ready to profit yours, CH: HOOLE.
closer.dateline: From my Schoole in Goldſmiths alley. Aprill 21. 1652,

div.head: Childrens Talke. Engliſh and Latine.
Puriles Confabulatiunculae Anglo La • in ae.

row.cell: Certaine Complements, and other more uſefull Forms of ſpeaking.
Salutationes quaedam & aliae loquendi Formulae uſitatiores.
A generall Complement at any time.
SAlve, Sis Salvus. Jubeo te ſalvere, Ave.
† We ſpeak to many in the plural number,
Habeo tibi gratiam, Habetur tibi à me gratia.
In the departure at any time.

cell.hi: And God be with you too.

row.cell: In the morning we thus give one the time of the day.

cell.hi: God give you a good day.

row.cell: To one that ſneezeth we ſay,
To one that is a doing any work.
To one at dinner or ſupper.

cell.hi: I drink a whole pot to you,
Here's to you half a glaſs.

row.cell: When we refuſe meat or drink.

cell.hi: Truly I cannot drink ſo much.
Now verily I am not able to pledge you.
I beſeech you to ſpare me.
I have no mind to eat any more.

row.cell: I have ſatisfied my appetite, or, I have ſtayed my ſtomack very well.

cell.hi: I would have no more at this time.

row.cell: To one who is come home out of a ſtrange country we ſay

cell.hi: I am glad you are come well home againe.
I am beholding to you for your kindneſſe.

row.cell: When the beere or wine is brought to the table.

cell.hi: Quando ce • viſia, aut vinum infertur menſae.

row.cell: Precor ut haec cerviſia vobis proſits
Faxit Deus, ut, fit vobis hoc vinū ſalutare.
When one is invited to a dinner or ſupper.

cell.hi: Quando vocatur aliquis ad prandium vel coenam,
My father bade me to come hither, and intreat you, that you would pleaſe to be his gueſt to day.

row.cell: Pater me juſſit huc rogatum te venire, ut hodie velis ejus eſſe conviva.

cell.hi: My maſter bade me to intreat you very earneſtly that you would dine with him to day.

row.cell: Herus te magnopore juſſit orare, ut apud ſe prādére velis hodiè.

cell.hi: Sir, my hoſt intrea's you, if you be not invited any whither eiſe, you would come and ſup with him at even.

row.cell: Rogat te meus hoſpes, praeceptor obſervande, ſi non aliò vocatus, ut caenatum ad ſe venias veſperi.

cell.hi: My Father and Mother have bidden ſome friends to ſupper, and deſire you to bear them company: wherfore you ſhall doe them a wonderful great kindnes. If you pleaſe to come.

row.cell: Parentes mei vocaverūt amicos aliquot ad caenam, his cupiunt te adeſſe: quarè mi ū in modum gratificàberis illis;
Then you may anſwer thus. My child, I hartily thank your father: But I cannot he at any feaſt by reaſon I am not well.
Tunc ſic reſpondére licébit Ego patri tuo, mi fili, magnam habeo gratiam. Verum ob adverſam valetudinem non valeo ulli convivo intereſſe.

cell.hi: Doe you likewiſe thanke your maſter heartily from me.

row.cell: Tu viciſſim hero tuo, nomine meo, magnas ages gratias.

cell.hi: But tel him I cannot come at this time.

row.cell: Verum hoc tempore dices me non poſſe venire.

cell.hi: I ſhould not need intreating if other occaſions did not hinder me.

row.cell: Haud páterer me rogari, ſi non me detinerent alia negótia.

cell.hi: I doe not ſay nay, eſpecially ſeeing I can ſee nothing readie here.

row.cell: Non abnuo, praeſertim cùm nihil hic parâtū eſſe videam.

cell.hi: Tell your father and mother, that I will come preſently.

row.cell: Renuntia paréntibus tuis, me conſeſtim eſſe venturum.

cell.hi: I am glad you are come.
You are come at a wiſh.

row.cell: How leave is to be asked.

cell.hi: I pray you maſter, give me leave.

row.cell: Praeceptor obſervande, fac mihi, quaeſo, poteſtatem.

cell.hi: To ſay the catechiſm to the miniſter.

row.cell: To fetch me ſome paper, books, &c.

cell.hi: Andrew did not do his duty to the miniſter.
This boy did not put off his bat, when he went by a magiſtrate.

row.cell: Hic non detexit caput, cum praeteriret magiſtrátum.

cell.hi: No body will ſay the leſſon.
Iames never ſalutes his father and mother.
Hee will not get out of my place.

row.cell: Non vult cédere de meo loco.

cell.hi: He hath all to be piſt my ſhooes.
He will not let me mind my booke.
He will not let me write.
He pulled me by he haire.
How old are you: One, two, three, ſix, eight, ten, eleven, twelve, yeares old.

row.cell: Quot annos natus es? Unū, duo, tres, ſex, octo, decim, undécim, duodecim.

cell.hi: Of what years are you? of one, two, ten, &c.

row.cell: Quot annorum es? unius, duorum, decem, &c.

cell.hi: What yeare are you going on?
On my firſt ſecond &c. What a clock is it?

row.cell: Aemilia the mother, and Battus the ſon.
My child Battus, my child, my Battus.

cell.hi: Batte fili, mi fili, mi Batte.
I pray you let me reſt mee a little longer.

row.cell: Sine me obſecro, adhuc paululum requieſcere.
How many hours have I ſlept.

cell.hi: I would I might ſleep my belly full.
See what fine weather it is a broad.

row.cell: Cerne, q • ám ſudum eſt foris.
What is that to me, whether it be fair weather or foul?
Quid ad me attinet, ſudum ſit an nebuloſum?
Looke the ſun too is come to ſee how you doe.

cell.hi: I can hardly get away this drouſineſſe.

row.cell: Rouſe up your body, (man,) and ſleep will be gone preſently.
Look you where it is, it lies under the bolſter.
I will not, doe but you goe away.
Col. 2. Cornelius the ſon, Dorothie the mother.

cell.hi: Mother: what a clock is it?

row.cell: What do you ſay ſir; are you taught no better manners?
Quid tu ais? ſicine doctus es?
Should you not ſalute me firſt?
And to you. Now aske what you would have.

cell.hi: Et tibi, Nunc quaere, quid vis.

row.cell: I pray you, good mother, tell me.
What would you have me tell you?

cell.hi: Its at the hand of ſix.

row.cell: Hath it ſtruck, or not yet?
I doe not thinke it hath ſtruck.
Indeed I have not heard it ſtrike.

cell.hi: I am terribly affraid of my maſters hand.

row.cell: You may be afore your maſter if you doe not loyter by the way.

cell.hi: Potes praevertere magiſtrum, ſi non ceſſes,
I thinke I had beſt do ſo

row.cell: But ſoe as you go not away hence uncombd or unwaſh'd.
At ità, ut ne impexus hinc abeas, aut illótus.
When I come againe, then I will waſh me.
Nay, but waſh you now rather.
I beſecch you good mother, let me goe now, leſt I be whipt.
Obſecro te, mea mater ſine me nunc abîre, ne vapulem.
Col. 3. Evaldus the maſter, Francis theſchallar.

cell.hi: Whence come you ſo late? ho you ſirrah:

row.cell: Unde venis tam ſeró? heus tu.
Heard you not the ſound of the bell?
I could not heare it, worthy maſter.
What? no? were you deaf No.
Why could you not hear the bell then?

cell.hi: Qut non potuiſti ergò audire campanam?

row.cell: And my mother did not awake me.
Connot you awake unleſſe you be called up?

cell.hi: Non tu potes expergiſci, ni ſuſciteris?

row.cell: Will you not be angry, if I confeſſe the truth?
No, unleſſe you tell an untruth.
Unleſſe ſome body call mee up, I ſhould not awake, I think, before noon, I ſleep ſo ſoundly.
Niſi qui ſquam ſuſcitet me non evigilem, credo, ante mérdiemque, tam ſuaviter dormio.
Will you get up earlier hereafter?

cell.hi: Truly I will doe my endeavour.

row.cell: Do ſo. I pardon you to day, becauſe you told the truth. Get you hence to your fellows.
Ita facito. Hodiè ignoſcitur tibi, quia verum confeſsus es. Abi hinc ad ſodales tuos.
I give you immortall thanks moſt reverend maſter.
Ago tibi gratias immortáles, reverendiſſime praeceptor.

cell.hi: Have you not room enough there?

row.cell: No. Nor can I make any roome.
But I adviſe you, get quickly out of my lap.
A • egote admoneo, ut abſcedas propè de meo ſinu.
But doe you ſhew me, where elſe I may ſit.

cell.hi: At tu mihi demonſtra, ubi alioqui ſedeam.

row.cell: And where do the dogs ſit?
But doe you know how you ſit?

cell.hi: But now thou lieſt me along thy back.
Thou ſhalt never uſe me thus and eſcape with it.

row.cell: Hoc tu mihi impunè nunquam ſéceris.

cell.hi: I care not a pin for thy threatnings.
Begin what you will, you ſhall meet with your match.
But you ſhall not box me and get nothing. I would have you know this too.

row.cell: At tu mihi pugnum impunè non mpinges; hoc te ſcirê etiam volo.
Now verily, but that I am afraid of the maſter my fiſt ſhould have flown about your ears a good while ago.
Enimveró, niſipraeceptorem métuerem, jamdúdum, pugnus in malâ haeréret.
If thou wilt any thing with me, call me forth after eight a clock.

cell.hi: Si quid vis, poſt horam octavam evoca.

row.cell: I dare you forth, come away.
I will take my brakefaſt firſt, that I may be the ſtronger. Thou muſt tarry for me ſo long.

cell.hi: Jentāculum volo antea ſúmere, ut robuſtior ſim▪ Tam diu te oportet expectare.
I knew they were but brags which you made or you did but crack.

row.cell: Scibam bullas eſſe, quas j • ctabas.
You mad man, ſhould wee ſtand to fight here, that are devoted to the ſame ſtudies, & inſtructed in the ſame precepts of vertue: Fie upon thee with ſuch idle tales.
Inſâne, nos hic pugnémus iiſdem ſtudiis conſceráti, iiſdem virtútū praeceptis imbuti: Apagate cum tam frivolis fabulis.
Now I conclude the to be a gentleman indeed and one that will not be eaſily beaten.
Nunc te virum judico generoſum, & invictum.
Col. 5. Iohn the maſter, Lambert, Martin, Nicolas School-fellows.
Col. 5. Joannes praeceptor, Lābertꝰ, Martinus, Nicolaus, Condiſcipuli.
What a noiſe is there, boy, as though the maſter were away.
Quis iſtic eſt ſtrepitu' • , puer, quaſi dominus abſit?
About what doe you fall our, you youngſters?

cell.hi: De qua re conténditis, vos juvenes?

row.cell: Hee will not give mee my quil again, which he hath ſnarcht from me.

cell.hi: Non vult mihi reddere cálamum meum, quem eripuit.

row.cell: If he doe not doe it out of hand, let him looke for me with a rod.
Si non actútùm facit, expectet me cum virga.
Hee ſaid he would run away.

cell.hi: Doe yee hold him, and bring him to me.

row.cell: Vos cum retinete, & addticite ad me.

cell.hi: See, he bits me by the ſleeve.

row.cell: And I'll knock out all thoſe teeth of his, if hee doe not let goe preſently.
Ego illi etiam dentes iſtos omnes evellam, ſi non dimittit illicò,

cell.hi: He is a roguiſh boy, he ſcratches with his nailes too.
Why are you ſuch a wicked boy.

row.cell: Cúrnam tu es tam ſceleritus puer?
You have taken a pen away from that boy.

cell.hi: Why did he likewiſe cal me out of my name?

row.cell: Cur etiam mihi dedit nomen ignominioſum?
He will do ſo no more.
You ſaid you would run away.
* He is a fool that ſuffers himſelfe to be beat, when he may run away.
* Stultus, eſt qui ſe caedi pátitur, dum liceat fugere.
And you got hold of his ſleeve with your teeth,
I catcht at his hand & he pull'd away his hand, & I caught hold of his ſleeve.
Manum captabam, ſubduxit manum, cepi manicam.
* The very mice mak at the hands of them that hold them.
* Et mures tenentium ſe manus impetunt.
May not I doe the ſame, that the little mice do?

cell.hi: Non mihi idem liceat, quod muſculis.

row.cell: But mice are oft-times harmleſſe, when they are taken.

cell.hi: At mures ſapenúmeró innoxii ſunt, quando capiuntur.

row.cell: And I am harmleſſe. For I preſently reſtored, what I had taken away.

cell.hi: Et ego innoxius. Nam quod eripúeram, confeſtim reddidi,

row.cell: For feare of a rod forſooth.
* He is not deſperately bad, who refraines from doing ill for fear of puniſhment.
* Non eſt deplorátè malus, qui á maleficio metu mali ábſtinet.
I am content good maſter, ſo that I be not an ill talker.

cell.hi: Placet, bone praeceptor, dum ne ſim caco-lálus.
Haſt thou never a knif to lend me.

row.cell: Non babes cultellū quē des mihi commodátó
I have one indeed; but I have not one that I can lend you.

cell.hi: Habeo equidem; ſed quem tibi accomodem non habeo.

row.cell: It is but a young one, that I have; It will not come againe, if I ſuffer it to ſtraggle abroad.

cell.hi: Novitius eſt, quem habeo; non revertetur, ſi paetiar evagari.

row.cell: Be not afraid. I will ſtand but here as long as I uſe it.
Noli timere. Ego tantiſper hîc reſiſtam dum utor.
I will not let you have it.
Perchance thou haſt that which I loſt lately.
Have you loſt your knife then?
Will you heare what a one it was?
It was a very little one, and dull.

cell.hi: A red haft ſet with braſſe ſtuds.

row.cell: It had a hole at the top.
Thine was for all the world like that which I have
Tuus per omnia ſimilis fuit ei, quem ego habeo.

cell.hi: I pray you let me ſee it

row.cell: Well, looke at it your belly full.
Tell me of all loves, where gotſt thou this knife?

cell.hi: Dic amabo, ubi noctus e • iſtum cultellum?
Why do you ask ſuch a queſtion.
I have a reaſon to ask
I have no reaſon to make anſwer.

row.cell: Tel me plainly whence had you it?
Before it was beſhit, ſay thou.

cell.hi: You will allow me to gueſſe it?

row.cell: Of a young fellow a pedler.
Surely it is a ſtolne knife.
But dare you buy ſtolne goods?
Audes tu veró mercári res furtivas?

cell.hi: You are as ill as a thief.

row.cell: But why did you ſay this is a ſtolne knife?
Sed cur tu dicis hunc eſse cultrum furtivum?
Therefore I perſwade thee, to give me mine againe.

cell.hi: Ergo tibi ſuadeo, ut mihi reddas meum.
Thou ſhalt not carry it away from me ſo.

row.cell: Be quiet, I will make you by and by to give me it again whether you will or no.
Quieſce: Illico faxo, ut ut reddas ingratiis.
I'll go to the maſter: and tell him the matter in order. He will make you reſtore it.

cell.hi: Ad proeceptórem ibo, illi rem pandam ordine. I • te roget reſtituere.

row.cell: But I will tarry at home when I have aſked leave by and by; nor will I come to the ſchoole to day.
At ego, mox petitâ veniâ manebo domi, nec in ſcholam venturus 〈◊〉 hodiè.
Col. 7. Quirinꝰ a ſchollar. Reynerus the maſter, Sebaſtian a ſchollar.
Col. 7. Quirinus diſcipulus, Reynerus Praeceptor, Sebaſtianus diſcipulus.
Moſt reverend maſter, I pray you bid this boy give me my knife againe.

cell.hi: Colendiſſime praecepror, huic quaeſo impera, ut mihi reddai cultrum meum.

row.cell: Ho you firrha have you any thing that is this boyes?
Ecquid hobes, heus tu, quod eſt hujus?

cell.hi: How ſaucily do you anſwer me.

row.cell: Haſt not thou another boyes knife?
Nor have you any knife at all;
I have a little one. It is my own.
Looke where it is in my ſheath.

cell.hi: Ʋbi tu nactus es hunc cultellum?

row.cell: I have had it this whole moneth almoſt.
I doe not ask you that queſtion. But whence had you it?
Non iſtud quaerito. Sed unde habes?
Of a young Factor. He ſold it me.

cell.hi: Ab inſtitóre júvene. Is vendidit mihi.
The knife is better then the money you gave for it.

row.cell: Melius eſt culter quàm pretium quod dediſti.
I have made a good market, if it be ſo as you ſay.
Bonum feci mercimoniū ſi itá eſt ut tu dicis.
But this boy maintains it to be his.
It is not ſo. It is mine.

cell.hi: If he have loſt any thing he may go ſeek it

row.cell: I have taken nothing that is his or was his.

cell.hi: Ego nihil eripui quod illius ſit aut fúerit.
Will you refer your ſelfe to me?

row.cell: If I may have no wrong done me, I will.

cell.hi: Si mihi non fiat injuria, volo.
I would have no falling out betwixt you

row.cell: But I fall out with no body.
Sed ego cum némine con tendo.

cell.hi: Give this boy then his knfie againe.

row.cell: I doe not refuſe it, if he would give me my mony againe.

cell.hi: Non recúſo, ſi mihi pecuniam meam reſtituat.
Let him doe it out of hand.

row.cell: Give him his money again without any delay.
So it ſhould be. Of ſuch beginnings oft-times great heart-burnings ariſe even amongſt grown men.

cell.hi: Ita fiéri decet. Ex tálibus initiis ſaepè naſcuntur magnae ſimultátes, etiam inter adultos.

row.cell: Thomas the ſon, Vincence the moth r.
Mother, when ſhall I have my dinner?
By and by, if you can but tarry a little.

cell.hi: I muſt be gone out of band.

row.cell: Whither, O good Sir, ſo haſtily?
Whither is it fit for a ſcholar to goe?
To the very place of execution, forſooth.

cell.hi: It hath not ſtruck one yet.

row.cell: But we muſt be there before it ſtrike.
Why do you ſtand to aske? at every houre.
Why then doe you lye ſo long in a morning.
Cur ergò tam ſecúrè requieſcis manè?

cell.hi: I never doe it but I ſmart for it.

row.cell: Art thou more afraid of blowes after dinner, then after ſleep.

cell.hi: Itáne verbera magis times à prandio, quàm à ſomno.

row.cell: Looke one that may make you anſwer. If you will not give me any meat, I will goe without my dinner.
Quaere qui tibi reſpóndeat, Si mihi non vis dare cibum impranſus abibo.
Goe where you will. There is no body holds you. If you doe eate no dinner you will have a better ſtomach to your ſupper at night.
Abi quo vis. Nemo eſt qui detinet te. Si non prandes, veſperi caenabis libentius.
Col. 9 Andrew the Maſter Bartholmew the ſchollar.

cell.hi: Why come you later then the teſte to the ſchoole?

row.cell: Cur tu caeteris tardiùs venis ad ludum?
My mother bad me tarrie a little whileſt, ſhe got the pottage ready.
Mater juſſit me paululùm opperiri, dum paret holꝰ
When doth ſhe uſe to make pottage?
But now it is paſt one

This never did befall her afore. Beſides, becauſe ſhe was ſomewhat long in getting it ready, I did not tarry upon her ſlowneſſe becauſe I ſtood in awe forſooth of your command. And therefore I came hither without my dinner.
Nunquam hoc evenit illi ante hac. Quinetiam, cùm lentior eſſet in apparando, non ſum illius lentitúdinem remoratus vèritus nimirum tuum impèrium. Itaque impranſus horſum procurri.
Truly I pittie thee. But eat your ſupper more plentifully at night.
Miſeret me tui ſcilicet. Caeterùm veſperi coena liberaliús.
* Where one hath had little or nothing to his dinner, hee cannot looke for much plentie to his ſupper.
* Ubi parcè prandétur non coenatur liberaliter.
Col. 10. Cornelia the ſiſter Dionyſius the brother.
Col. 10. Cornelia ſoror, Dyonyſius fr • t • r.
Wil you ſleep al the day Get up I ſay that I may make the bed.
Vis totum diem ſtértere Surge, inquam, ut reconcinnem lectum.
Your maſter is gone into the ſchoole: and doe you ask whether it be time or no?
Prae ceptor tuus intravit in ludum: tu rogas num fit tempus?
How long is it ſince he went in?
What a clock is it then?
Alas, why do you let me ſleep ſo long?

cell.hi: Eheu, quid ſinis me tam diu dormire?

row.cell: Either you, or any one elſe of the houſe.

cell.hi: Vel tu, vel quilibet è familia.

row.cell: But how can you bee raiſed?
But I my ſelfe have called loud upon you, above ten times to no purpoſe.
At egomet ipſa, plúsquàm deci • s, te fruſtra inclamávi.
I indeed, and ſo loud, that you might have heard I think if you had been dead.
Et quidemica ſórtiter, ut ſi mortuus eſſes, audires credo.

cell.hi: I ſuppoſe it is a tale.

row.cell: If you had called, I ſhould have heard.
Unleſſe you had made as though you did not you might heare.
If I had heard I would have got up.

cell.hi: As readily indeed, as you uſe to doe.

row.cell: * I talk againſt a woman to no purpoſe.

cell.hi: Make haſte to get you ready unleſs you wil be knockt.

row.cell: Própera te induer'e, ni vis pulſari.
Hang the ſchoole and the maſter too.

cell.hi: Dii perdant phrontiſterium unà cum magiſtro.
Is that the beginning of your prayers?

row.cell: What ſhould I pray? I have more mind to curſe.
O moſt excellent principles of honeſtie!
I pray you get you gone and mind your kitchin-buſineſſe.
Abi, quaeſo te, & rem cua c u • liariam.
That ſhall be lookt too well enough when you are dead and rotten.
Illa curabitur rectè vel te extincto.
I pray you get you gone preſently, I cannot put on my cloths, whilſt you are by.
Abi, quaeſo te, denuo, non me poſſum induere re praeſente.
Are you become ſo baſhfull on a ſuddaine.
In the mean time, whileſt you prattle here. the time paſſeth: I muſt undergoe jerks which you will not feel.
Interea dum tu hic garris, abit hora; mihi parantur piagae, quas tu non ſenties.
In good truth you deſerve to be ſharpely corrected,
But I know what to anſwer the maſter.
At ego ſcio quid praeceptori reſpondeam.
What elſe I pray you then, that you are as ſleepy as a dormous?
Quid aliud, quaeſo quám te nihil eſſe inertius, nihil ſomniculoſius?

Forſooth that you ſleep ſo ſoundly that one may throw the houſe over your head, ſo far are you from waking of your ſelfe, either out of love to your booke, or for feare of your maſter, or reſpect to your Parents.
Nempe, quod ita ſecùrè dormias, ut nullo clamore poſſis excitáti, tantum abeſt ut evigiles tuâpte ſponte, vel amore l •• erarum, vel praeceptoris metu vel reverentiâ parentum.

cell.hi: You begin your wonted and old kind of preaching.

row.cell: I preach indeed, but to one that is deafe.
If you were a ſtranger, I know what I would doe.

cell.hi: Si fores aliena, ſcio quid facerem.

row.cell: You would beat us forſooth. Get you gone and be whipt.
Verberáres nos ſcilicet. Abi quo dignus es.
I beſeech you, for Gods ſake, give over pratling at the laſt.

cell.hi: Obſecro te, per omnes deos ut garrire tandem definas.

row.cell: I will not give over till you get up.
I cannot ſiſter, unleſſe you be gone.

cell.hi: Non poſsum, ni tu abeas, ſorer.

row.cell: I, and my mother too, ſo you be but gone, ſiſter.

cell.hi: Vel matrem, dum tu abeas ſoror.

row.cell: I will be gone and ſome body elſe ſhall come.
Col. 11. Eraſm 9 the ſchollar, Frederic 9 the maſter.
Come you hither too with your ſtaring head of haire.
Horſum tu quoque cum hirto capite.
I ſee it. But whence come you ſo late and ſo naſtie?
Video. Sed unde venis tam ſero, támque incultus.
Firſt out of my bed, and then out of our houſe

cell.hi: Eſtrato, primùm, deinde ex noſtris aedibus.

row.cell: That you come late, I now let this paſſe.
Ought you not to comb your head before you come to ſchoole?
Non tu debeas caput pectere, entequam venires ad ludum?
Why doe you not buy one?
My parents ſay they want money.
Sell ſome corne that you may have money.
But why doe you not ask to borrow a comb ſome where elſe then?
No body will lend us one.
We have almoſt all of us ſcabbed heads; and (I think) people avoid that.

cell.hi: Plerique omnes habémus capita ſcabióſa: id vitant (credo) hómines.

row.cell: Do your parents drink ſo many jugs of beer, and can they not ſpare ſo much from their throat, as to buy a comb?
Tot cyathos cerviſiae tui parentes exhauriuns: non tantum poſſunt detráhere gutturi ſuo, ut emant pectinem?
Either come me more handſome the ſchool, or come not at all.
Aut tu mihi compitor redi ad ludum, aut ne prorſus redi.
Col. 12. Godfrey the maſter, Hermanus the monitor.
I ſee here are a great many away, ho Moni tor, looke about you.
Permultos abeſſe video. heus cuſtos, circumſpecta.

cell.hi: See that you have the names of al ſet down that are away now.

row.cell: Vide ut omnium qui nunc abſunt, nomina deſcripta habeas.
Nay rather in a little paper which you may give me in my hand.

cell.hi: Imò in chártula, quam mihi tradas in manum.

row.cell: As ſoone as I ſhall come againe to the ſchoole.
In the mean time you ſhall take order, that I have ſome gentle rods provided.
Intérea curábis, ut mihi lent á rum virgarum ſint parati faſciculi.
If god bleſſe me to day, I will make them come together more diligently.
Si ſim ſalvus hodiè, efficiam ut ſtudioſiùs conveniatur.

cell.hi: I wiſh you take no thought for the rods,

row.cell: Secúrú eſſe jubeo, quantum ad virgas attinet.
You muſt be whip't you ſluggard.

cell.hi: I was going thither as faſt as I could.
The maſter hath given us leave to be gone.

row.cell: How early indeed? Is hath ſtruck eight a good while agoe.
Quām manè veròs Jamdudum ſonuit octáva.
Ho, tel me, did any body mention me?
Ebeu, dic mihi, c • qua ſuit mentio mei.
So it is. The maſter bade every one to be ſet down.
Sic eſt. praeceptor univerſos conſcribi juſſit.
Which? thoſe that were preſent, or thoſe that were abſent.
That is not well. For if he had bidden thoſe that were there to be ſet down, I could have alledged that I was left out.
Malè habet. Nam ſi praeſentes, conſcribi juſſiſset, ego me praeteritum eſte contenderem.
Ho, I am well enough if you ſay true.
Eho, ſalvus ſum, ſi verum dicis.
I will goe to him, and intreat him to put out my name.
Adibo, ac deprecábor, ut nomen meum diſpungat.

cell.hi: He wil not dare to deny me.
He will not be hired to it.

row.cell: Say not ſo. I know what he promiſed me.
Nè dixeris. Scio quid mihi pollicitus ſit.
Ye ſhall both be whipt if the maſter know it.
I leave that to God Almighties care.
Col. 14. Matthew the maſter, Neſtorius the monitor, Andrew, Peter, and Iohn, ſcholars.
Col. 14. Mathaus praecēptor. Neſtotius cuſtos, Andreas, Petrus & Ioannes diſcipuli.
Set me ſome rods, and the ferula ready monitor.
Where are the names of them that are away?

cell.hi: Come hither, why was you not here to day.

row.cell: My father bad me to go into the field; to ſee whether the ditchers were there or no.

cell.hi: Pater juſſti me abire in agrum, ut recognoſcer em an foſſores ibi adeſſent.

row.cell: You ſhould have came to me to aske leave to goe into the field.
Veniſſes ad me pétitum copiam abeundi in agrum.
I could not come hitherward, my father was ſo earneſt.
Non mihi licuit horſum ire, ſic inſtábat pater.
You ſhould have told him you could not be away from the ſchoole with out my leave.

cell.hi: Dixiſſes, te non poſſe abeſſe á ſchola ſine meo favére.

row.cell: I told him indeed, but I could not get leave of him to ſtep to you: he is ſo ſtrait in his commands.
Dixi quidem, ſed non impetravi ab eo facultátem tranſcurrendi ad te, ita imperioſus eſt.
* Your father hath command at home, and I in the ſchoole.
* Domi habet impérium pater, ego in ludo.
But my father bade me at home.
But I forbade any one to doe otherwiſe, then I will and command here.

cell.hi: At ego vetui quenquam ſecus fácere, quám hîc volo & jubeo.

row.cell: Would you not have us to obey our parents?

cell.hi: Non tu vis ut parentibus obſequamur?

row.cell: Why then am I now blamed for having done ſo?

cell.hi: Cur igitur nunc hoc ſeciſſe arguor?

row.cell: Away, away, we prolong the time with this bafling. Obey them both, as much as may be.
Abi, abi, tempus extráhimus hâc concertatione. Ʋtriſque pareto, quoad fieri poteſt.
Piſtor, come on, tell me what hindred you.

cell.hi: Piſtor, age, dic quid te detinúerit.

row.cell: Truly I roſe ſoon after foure a clock, bu: preſently I was to bolt the meale: that labour laſted me almoſt an houre and a halfe. And afterwards whileſt I was a waſhing and drying my ſelfe, and getting on my ſtockings, & making my ſelfe ready, the time ſlipt a way.
Equidem ſurrexi ſtatim poſt horam quartam, ſed illico debui farinam ſubigere: is labor durávit fere ſeſqui horam. Poſtea verò dum lavor, dum areſco, dum induo caligas, & compáro me, abit tempus,
Whileſt you ſtand ſo to repeate thoſe things in order to me, you loſe time.
Dum tu mihi iſta ſic refer: órdine, perdis tempus.
But, moſt learned maſter, unleſſe I ſhould loſe time on this faſhion, I ſhould gaine my ſelfe blowes.
Atqui, praeceptor dôctiſſime, ni tempus hoc pacto perderem, lucrifácerem mihi plagas.
Ye are al prettie nimble in excuſing your ſelvs, but not ſo in learning. Goe your way. Call the reſt.
Omnes eſt is in excuſando argútuii, diſcendo non item. Abi, récita caeteros.

cell.hi: What every day thus forſooth? you bring ſometimes one thing and ſometimes another, but what have you now to ſay for your ſelfe?

row.cell: Nempe hoc aſſidué? alias aliud adfers; Quid vero nunc profers in excuſationem tui?
Good maſter we had a many gueſts yeſternight.

cell.hi: Heri veſperi, praeceptor optime, multos convivas excepimus.

row.cell: Theſe ſat up till midnight, and I might not ſtir one jot from them and therefore I could not awake ſooner. I have no more to ſay.
Hi deſiderunt uſque ad mediam noctem, nec mihi licuit batum unguem ab eis diſcedere. Propcerea non potui evigilare maturiùs. Dixi.
Why did not you invite me too amongſt the gueſts.

cell.hi: Cur me quoque inter cateros convivas, non vocaſti?

row.cell: I will worke with my parents, that you may be bidden now and then if you will ſo.
Tránſigam apud parentes, uti vocêris non nunquam, ſi ita vis.
Doe you promiſe you will do that ſo for me?
I promiſe you in good deed.
See you do not deceive mee.
It ſhall not be long of me, if you be not invited.
Per me quinem non ſtabit, quò minùs vocáberis.
You are a good honeſt young man, ſee you be diligent at your booke too.
Frugi es adoleſcens, cura ut ſis item ſtudioſus.

cell.hi: Get you hence into your place.

row.cell: Doe you bid me call the reſt.

Not at this time. I will not beguile the whole company of their leſſon, for the ſlothfullneſſe of a few. But remember this boyes, hereafter you ſhall not at all excuſe your abſence? Whoſoever ſhall he a way, without my leave ſhall be whip't.

Minimè hoc tempore. Nolo univerſum gregem fraudáre ſuâ praelectione ob paucorum inertiam. Vetùm hoc meminéritis pueri, poſthac nequicquam excuſabitis abſentiam, Quiſquis ſine meo favore abfuerit, vapulábit.
Col. 15. Oſwald the maſter Paulus a ſchollar and the company of boyes.
Col. 15. Oſvaldus praeceptor Paulus diſcipulus, puerorum grex.
Thinke upon theſe things ſeriouſly which we now read,
Meditámini diligen èr ea, quae nunc praelégimus.

cell.hi: We will be ſure to do it.

row.cell: Maſter if you know not it hath ſtruck eight.
Be quiet a little boyes after I have ask't • his boy what I will I wil preſently diſmiſs you all Doe you anſwer me.
Quié • cite puſillúm, pueri, Poſtquam hunc interrogávero, quae volo, illico dimittam, omnes vos. Tu mihi reſponde.
Doe you know what you ought to doe?

cell.hi: Tu ſcis quidte facere opo? teat?

row.cell: By and by when you come home.
Am I to do any thing beſids what I am wont.
What are you wont to doe?
If I be uncomb'd or unwaſh'd, I comb'd mee and waſh me.

cell.hi: Si impexus ſim aut illétus pecto, lavóque.

row.cell: I get my breakfaſt, and come againe to the ſchoole as ſoone as poſſibly can be.
Nothing indeed. If any thing elſe ſhould be done, I pray you put me in mind.

cell.hi: Nihil ſanè. Si quid praeterea fieri decet, admone, quaeſo.

row.cell: Whenſoever you goe into the houſe, you ſhould never goe in without ſaying ſomething.

cell.hi: Quocunque tempore demum ingrederis, nunquā debes domum tacitus introire.

row.cell: What doe you ſay when you goe in?
Very good reaſon. But if your mother be away, whom doe you ſalute?

cell.hi: Meritiſſin è. Sinmater ab eſt, quem ſalutas?

row.cell: If I ſee her no where, I ſalute the folks of the houſe.

cell.hi: Si illam nuſquam conſpicor, ſalúto familiam.

row.cell: But if your father ſhall come in after doe you not ſalute him?

cell.hi: Sin pater poſtea ingrediétur, non ſalútas?

row.cell: No For I thought I had diſcharged my dutie, if I ſaluted once.

cell.hi: Minimè. Credidi me perſunctum officio, ſi ſalútem ſemel.

row.cell: Nay but, ſuch reſpect is eſpecially due to your father.

cell.hi: Imò, patri talis honor debetur imprimis.

row.cell: I did not know ſo much.
What if my father doe neither ſee me, nor ſpeak to me?

cell.hi: Quid ſi me pater nec videat, nec alloquátur?

row.cell: Nevertheles, you ſhould come to him of your own accord, and put of your hat and make a leg, and give him an honorable complement.

Nihilominus ultr òdebes tu eum accèd re, detecto
que capite flectére poplitem & honorificè ſalutáre.
In other words, then we uſe to ſalute other men?

cell.hi: Aliiſne verbis, quàm quibus caeteros hómines ſalutáre ſolémus?

row.cell: God ſave you moſt dear father, or thus, God ſpeed you father.
Salve, patet chariſſime; vel ſic, Salvus fis, mi pater.
If he ask you any thing. anſwer him freely like a man, what you know
Si quid interrogabit, reſpondebis, quod ſcis, humaniter.
Take heed you take no diſtaſte at any thing that he ſaith or doth.

cell.hi: Cave tibi quicquam diſplictat eorum, quae vel dicit vel facit.

row.cell: I am not ſo ſqueamiſh, that my fathers doings or words ſhould diſpleaſe me.
Non ſum tam faſtidioſꝰ ut patris mibi facta diſplicant, aut verba.

cell.hi: Bee ready to obey him at every command.
I will not doe it that I know on.

row.cell: Moreover, if, when he is angry he ſhall talke aloud, endure his chiding and ſay nothing.
Porro, ſi quando offenſus detonabit, perferto tacitus increpatiónem ipſius.
What? If I have deſerved nothing.
* Learn to bear even a unjuſt chiding, eſpecially from a parent.
*Etiam injuſtam objurgationem diſce ſuſtinere, praeſertion à parente.

cell.hi: I will ende about the beſt I can.

row.cell: * You ought to reverence and reſpect both your parents alike.
* Utrumquè parentem debts colere ac venèrári pari obſervantia.
So I doe, though no body bid me.
If you doe it, doe it ſtil: but if not, be ſure to doe it.
Si quidem facis, perge fā cere: ſin minùs, ſedulo fácito.
I will omit nothing with my good will
You ſay honeſtly. Boyes what I have taught this one boy, I would have you all taught the ſame.
Honeſtè dicis. Pueri, quae unum hunc edócui, omnes eadem edoctos volo.
Now get you to breakfaſt, and come again about nine a clock.
Nunc ite jentatum & redite ſub horam nonā.
Col. 16. Quintine the maſter, Robert the monitor, Servat • us a ſcholar.
Col. 16. Quintus praeceptor, Robertus monitor, Servatius diſcipulus.
Who hath the bill for ſpeaking engliſh.

cell.hi: Why do you ſpeak ſo loud?

row.cell: Should I not ſpeak aloud when he dare be bold to ſay ſuch things openly?
Non vociferer, quum hic talia audeat praedicáre.

cell.hi: Why ſhould I not bee bold to ſay it when it is true?

row.cell: Quid ni audeam, cum ſit verum.
Thou lyar! but when did you heare mee ſpeake Engliſh?
O falcide! Quando veró audiviſti me loquentem Anglice?
I pray you tell mee. On what day; or in what place?
Die ſodes, quo die? aut ubi gentium;

cell.hi: I have forgotten the day, I do not remember the place,

row.cell: Dies éxcidit mihi, Locum non commémini.
Truly I doubt whether I ſhould beleive.
Good maſter, I beſeech you, if any one ſay the truth, that he may be beleived.

cell.hi: Si quis verum dicit, quaeſo ut credâtur, bone magiſter.
I maintain that you ſpoke Engliſh.

row.cell: Nay rather do you prove that you did not ſpeak it.

cell.hi: Imó tu proba te non dixiſse.

row.cell: I cannot. IF it were lawful for me to take my oath, I would not ſticke to ſweat by all the ſaints in the Kalendar.
Non poſſum. Si mihi liceat jusjurandum interponere, nihil dubitem per omnes adjurare divos.
I have very great wrong done me, moſt worthy maſter.
Inſignis mihi fit injuria, praecepter optime.
Did you never ſpeake Engliſh before?

cell.hi: Nunquam antehac protuliſ • t vernaculū ſermonem?

row.cell: It is credible then that you ſpake Engliſh too, when he ſet you down.

cell.hi: Credibile eſt tum quoque dixiſſ • e verná ulum, cùm hic te notáret.

row.cell: He lies like a rogue; I neither ſpoke Engliſh when he was by, nor did he ſet me down.
Mentitur ſurcifer nece. go vernacalum locutus ſum, hoc praefente, nec iſte-notávit.
Now verily, I cannot but laugh. And I know not whether I ſhould believe. This boy never told me a lie before this day, you have once or twice, which now indeed mak's your cauſ • the worſe.
Rideo mehércu'è. Nec ufri credam ſcio. Hic mihi nunquā mentitus eſt ante hunc diem, tu ſemel at que iterū, quod nunc ſane tuam cauſam reddit deteriorem.
I acknowledge I have done amiſs in lying aforetime, but now indeed I ſpeak the truth I have not offended maſter.
Agnoſco peccaſſe olim mentiendo at nunc profecto verum dico, nihil deliqui praeceptor.

cell.hi: Would you have me believe you?

row.cell: You may ſafely belive me, worthy maſter.
Good maſter either believe both, or beleive neither.
Praeceptor bone, vel crede utrique, vel crede neutri.
I have light upon a couple of wranglers for ought that I ſee. Get you both hence with a miſchief. Doe you keep the note.
In diſceptatores incidi, ut video. Auſerte vos hinc ambos in malam rem. Tu ſignum retine.

cell.hi: Withall my heart, ſeeing you wil have it ſo.

row.cell: Col. 17. Theodore an old man, and Venantius a ſchollar.
Have you a pen and inke child?
Yes ſir. If you wil have any thing I wil furniſh you.
Euam dómine. Si quid vis ſuppeditábo.

cell.hi: I would write two or three words.

row.cell: Yea, write ten if you wil

cell.hi: I will goe no whither write as much as you will.

row.cell: Nuſquam digrédiar, ſcribe, quantum vis prolixè.
Tak your pen and ink again, child, I have ſet down what I had a minde to ſet down. I thanke you.
Recipe, fili, calamárium tuum, notavi quae volui. Habetur tibi gratin.
Why ſhould you thanke me? ſhould an old mā thanke a boy eſpecially for no ſervice?

cell.hi: Quid mihi, gratiam habeas? ſenex adoleſcentulo praeſertim ob nullum officium?

row.cell: Your manuerly ſaying ſets me on, child, ſo that I have a mind to talk with you a litle, if you be content.
Honeſt a oratio tua, mi fili, 〈…〉 , ut tecum colloqui velim paulifper, ſi ánnuis.
I am not unwilling indeed to talke with you Sir: but I wonder what the matter is that you would ſpeak with me.
Non abnuo quidem tecum loqui, domine: ſed quid ſit miror, quod mecum loqui velis.
I would firſt know of you, who is your father and mother.
Scire ex te primum volo, qui ſint parentes tui.
They dwell not here, & therefore I ſhould name them to you but in vain

cell.hi: Non hîc habitant, proinde fruſtra eos nóminem tibi.
That is a place altogether unknown to me.

row.cell: I believe you Sir. It is not ſo much frequented as this.

cell.hi: Credo domine. Non eſt tam céleber, quàm hic eſt.

row.cell: Is that, that Wert, a good town or a countrey-village?

cell.hi: Oppidum eſt, an pagus Guerteum iſtud?

row.cell: A good town, indeed, & that very populous. It is commonly called Wert.
Oppidum ſarè, & quidem populoſiſſimum. Vulgò vocátur Wert.
Now I know it: There is great ſtore of cloathing in that place.
Nunc ſcio: magnum exercetur lanificium in eo loco.
I thaught you had been a ſcholar.
How fals it out then, that you come hither to learn.

cell.hi: Quid igitur áccidit, ut huc ſtudendi cauſâ advenias?

row.cell: I do not learn here. but in my own countrey. Now I came hither for my minds ſake with my father to the Mart.
Non hic ſtudeo ſed in patriâ. Nunc huc animi cauſâ cum patre profectus ſum ad mercátum

cell.hi: Now have you brought me into my way againe.

row.cell: Nunc me redux ſti in viam.
By whom then art thou taught?
By the ſchoole-maſters of that place where I was born.

cell.hi: A ludimagiſtris iſtius loci ubi natus ſum.

row.cell: What like maſters have you there?
The one leane, the other fat.
Are they batchelours or married men?
Are they men of great learning, i e. great ſcholars?
I doe not know truly. I think indifferent.
Truly that which we do not know It is a fond anſwer ſir, but I hope you will pardon it.
Herclè quod neſcimus. Ridicula eſt reſponſio, Domine, ſed ignoſcenda.
I like it well enough. Is any of your ſchool fellowes a very good ſchollar?
placet. Ecquis inter condiſcipulos tuos eſt inſignitèr doctus?

cell.hi: Herein I am not able to anſwer you.

row.cell: Can they ſay any thing what one will in Latine?
I thinke ſo. I am ſure they prattle every day in Latine.

cell.hi: Have you done any good at your learning?

row.cell: Ecquid operae pretium feciſti in literis?
I am not able to judge of my learning.

cell.hi: Ego meam eruditionem non poſſum aeſtimáre.
Shall I make tryall of you?

row.cell: I doe not ſay nay. If you will you may.
Can you ſay any verſe by heart?

cell.hi: To pleaſe great men deſérves no little praiſe.

row.cell: Princibus placuiſſe viris, non ultima laus eſt.

cell.hi: It is not the laſt praiſe, to pleaſe chief men.

row.cell: Non eſt ultima laus, Placuiſſe principibus viris.

cell.hi: It is not the laſt praiſe.

row.cell: That it is exceeding great praiſe; expreſſed by the contrary, like as we ſay a boy is not unlearned, whom we would ſay is learned.

cell.hi: Quòd ſit laus eximia; per contrárium expreſſa, ſicut dicimus, pú • rum quempiam non eſſe indectum, quem doctum volumus dicere.

row.cell: That which is laſt in order, but here, as oft other-where it is put for the leaſt, or very little, or the loweſt, as the firſt is put for the chief & moſt excellent

cell.hi: Quod eſt ordine poſtremum, verùm hic, ut & aliás ſaepe pro minimo aut exiguo, aut inſimo ponitur, quemádmodum primus pônitur pro ſummo & eximio.

row.cell: What part of ſpeech is Ultima?
My maſter reckoned it amongſt the Nounes ordinal. For he is not wont to diſpute curiouſly about ſuch matters.

cell.hi: Meus magiſter retulit inter nómina ordinália. Nam de tálibus rebus non ſoles anixè diſputáre.

row.cell: And he had rather have ſuch ſchollars as can tell how to uſe words then how to wrangle about them.
Et ipſe diſcipulos habére mavult, qui ſciant vocibus ut, quám qui de illis degladiári noverint.
Whence is the infinitive Mood, placuiſſe governed, or upon what doth it depend?
Infinitum placuiſſe unde regitur, aut á quo pendet.

I thinke this may bee ſpoken two ways: firſt that it dependeth on the Verb eſt, ſo that an Accuſative caſe may be underſtood; as the old faſhion is for Verbs to have an accuſative caſe after them with an Infinitive mood, as this may be the conſtruction: It is not the laſt praiſe (underſtand) for a man to pleaſ great men: that it may be like this ſpeech * It is fit for a ſchollar to love his maſter. Again it may be ſaid that the Infinitive mood placuiſſe is put inſtead of a nominative caſe, as it is for the moſt part; that it may be like this ſpeech. To love is a moſt hurtfull thing; or this, to play at dice is a moſt hurtfull thing.

Duplicit'r hoc poſſe dici exiſtimo: Primùm, quòd pendeat á verbo eſt, ut ſubaudiatur Accuſativus, ſicut mos eſt verb is priſtinus accuſativum poſt ſe régere cum infinito; ut ſit iſta conſtructio: Non eſt ultima laus (ſubaudi) hominem placuiſſe vitis principibus: ut ſit ſimilis huic orationi.

* Eſt aequum diſcipulum amare praeceptorem. Deinde, poteſt dici, quòd infinitum placuiſſe ponátur vice Nominativi, ſi cut plerun
que ut ſit, huic orationi ſimilis, A máre eſt res damnoſiſſima; vel huic. Ludere álcâ non eſt honeſtum.
By chiefe men I think are meant men that are mightie, Noble, rich and the like, that chiefe may be put here inſtead of a noune Adjective, as it is uſed in Lucius Florus, the chief people.
Per principes viros puto ſignificari viros praepotentes, nòbiles, divites, & similes: ut princeps hîc ponátur loco nominis Adjectior, ſicut apud Lucium Florum uſurpatur Princeps pópulus.
Nor is that any ſtrange thing; For Terence alſo ſaid an old Merchant. And an old wife as cunning as a fox is to be found in Eraſmus.
Nec id novum eſt; Nam & ſenex mereator dixit Terentius.
What kinde of verſe is this?
In the firſt four feet of a Spondie, & Dactyle indifferently: in the fift of a dactyle onely; in the ſixt of a Spondie or Trochie.

cell.hi: In quatuor primis pedibus indifferenter ex Dáctylo, vel Spondaeo: in quinto è ſolo Dáctylo; ïn ſexto, Spondaeo: vel Trochaeo.

row.cell: How many ſylables hath a Dactile foot?
The firſt long, and the latter two ſhort.
Do your maſters teach you theſe things?
I beſeech you, from whence elſe ſhould I learn them?

cell.hi: He muſt needs be a rich man.

row.cell: Becauſ they get a great deal of money, that teach boyes ſo.
Quia magnum quaeſtum faciunt, qui ſic erudiunt adoleſcentes.
But our maſter hath much adoe to live.
At noſter vix ſeſe á penuria tuétur.
Truely, he deſerves a better fortune.
So he doth indeed: but he cannot make fortune his friend.
Ita eſt quidem: ſed non peteſt fortunae litáre.

cell.hi: How doth he and the citizens agree?
They all ſtrive to doe him any kindneſſe.

row.cell: Hee doth ſo much the more deſerve their baunty.
Your common-wealths are able, but ours are not ſo.

cell.hi: Veſtrae Reſpúblicae potentes ſunt, at noſtrae non item.

row.cell: Good and diligent at their bookes.
You do well. But can you tell me readily, why you love him.
Honeſtè facis. At verò potes mihi expedire, cur ames?
Firſt, becauſe he is a good ſchollar.
He is worthily beloved of all good men for his learning.

cell.hi: Ob eruditiónem amátur méritò ab omnibus bonis.

row.cell: And then becauſe he is ſo diligent in teaching us.

cell.hi: Delnde, quod in docendis nobis tam diligens ſit.

row.cell:
In this reſpect
• e owe him a great deale of honour and love too.
Hoc nomine vos illi potiſſimum debetis honórem pariter & amórem.
And alſo becauſe hee chides no body but gently.

cell.hi: Tum quód néminem niſi clementér objúrget.

row.cell: Truly he deſerves to be a Tutor to a Prince.
Dignus herclè, qui regum liberos dóceat.
Nor doth he ever beate any unleſſe he be admoniſhed a fore.

cell.hi: Necunquam caedit quenquam niſi admónitum antcà.
He is a good man, as far as I can beare.

row.cell: Beſides all this. He doth ſo provoke all to follow their books, and to live well, that a Mother cannot more kindly win her child to ſuck or eat.
Ad haec univerſos ſic próvocat ad literárum ſtudium & honeſtatem, ut non poſſit mater benigniùs provocare ſuum infantem ad ſugendum, aut edendum.

cell.hi: He muſt needs be a naughty boy that lovs not ſuch a maſter.

row.cell: Júvenis ſit improbus, qui praeceptorem talem non amer.
Therefore I ſaid I did love him, leſt I ſhould be thought a naughty boy.

cell.hi: Ergò me dixi amare, njuvenis cenſear improbus.

row.cell: I have asked you my childe, what I had a minde to, now I let you go.
Percontátus ſum, fili, quae volui. Nunc te dimitio.
And when you come to your maſter, comend me kindly to him.
Et praeceptorem tuum meo nomine fac officioſe ſalutes adveniens,

cell.hi: I will doe it indeed with all my heart.

row.cell: Col. 18 Arnold the maſter, Bernard the ſcholar.
Is there any among you that hath a good mind to play?

cell.hi: Ecquis inter vos eſt ludendi cúpidus?

row.cell: We all of us indeed deſire that.

cell.hi: What will you give me if I grant you leave to play?

row.cell: Quid dābitis mihi ſi vobis ſáciam ludendi copiam.

cell.hi: We will all love you moſt dearly.

row.cell: In what will you ſhew that love.

cell.hi: Quâ in re declarábitis iſtum amórem;

row.cell: We will conſtantly obey your commands.
We will never diſpleaſe you; we will ply our books as faſt as we can
Nunquam offendémus: ſummam operam impendémus in ſtudendo.
What puniſhment ſhal I inſtict upon you, in caſe you deceive me?
Impoſe what puniſhment you will, or keepe us here perpetually hereafter bound in this priſon, like a company of melefactors.

cell.hi:
Quamvis p • nam ir • og ••
to, aut nos • îc perpetu • deinceps, tanquam maleficos, de • inéto vinc • o • in h • c cárcere.
I yeild to what you ſay, I like the motion.

row.cell: Sententiae veſt • ae accédo Place • conditio.

cell.hi: Play al; but ſo as to behave your ſelvs civi • y.

row.cell: I would ſome ill chance or other might light upon our maſter.

cell.hi:
Ʋt o • nes dii, d • ae
que praeceptórem noſtrum magno • onent infortunio.
What harm hath the maſter done you that you ſo ſtorm againſt him?

row.cell: Quid magiſter malefécit tibi, ut ſic in • um deſtomachéris?
Becauſe he lets us ſit drowſing here in ſuch faire weathrr.
Quòd nos hîc • am ſer • no coelo deſidére patiatur.
At other times when it is either rain or ſtormmy weather, he will ſuffer himſelfe to be
over▪intreated▪ but now there is no intreating of him.
Aliàs, quando v • l pluvi • eſt, vel prócella, patietur ſe exorari; nunc inexorábilis eſt.

cell.hi: I had a good mind to play a good whie •• nce

row.cell: You wax ſottiſh. Wee plaid but the day before yeſterday; and have you forgot it already.
Déſipis núdius tértius luſimus; an id éxcidit tibi?
But the windes and ſhowers were ſo boyſterous that day, that I had no minde to look out of the doors.
Verùm illo die ſic venti ſaeviébant, & imbres, ut mihi non libé. et proſpectáre domo.
Could our maſter foreknow what weather would happen?

cell.hi: An magiſter potuit praeſcire quid • venturum eſset.

row.cell: I am ſure on it, when we were diſmiſſed, it was fair.
But a little after we were gone from the ſchool (O wonderfull!) what a mighty tempeſt there aroſe on a ſuddain!
At paulo poſt quam ſumus ludum egr • ſſi, (Deum immortalem!) quanta tempeſtas ſubito coorta eſt!
Seeing you are ſo deſirous to play what, I pray you, have you a mind to doe?
Cùm ludendi tam ſis cupidus, quid quaeſo, tibi libet actitáre?
That which I might not doe of late.
And what is that I pray you?
To run up and downe the fields, to leape in the meadowes, and to fill the aire with ſhouting
In campis currere, in pr • is exul á • e, magnis clamoribus vácuum impl • te coe • um.
O ſtrange I what a fine ſport is that?
Dii beni! quanta eſt ea voluptas!
Doe you not know? I had rather have this ſport then eat honey, or ſugar.
Non ſcis? Ego prae hâc voluptáte, ne mel quidem eſitáre velim aut ſaccharum.
I remember our maſters ſpake of ſome other exerciſes.

cell.hi: Ego magiſtros noſtros alia quaedam exercitia memorare commémmi.

row.cell: There cannot be better found in my judgment.

cell.hi: Non poſſunt melióra reperiri, meo quidem judicio.

row.cell: What do you think of the handball.
I never uſed my ſelf to that kind of play: and beſids, my ſtrength will not abide it, nor have I the trick of it
Nunquam exercui me iſto ludendi génerè: deinde, nec vires ſupperunt, nec artem cáſteo.
Whether? Angling, or fiſhing with the net?
Truly I am delighted with neither.
The one makes ut ſlo • hfull, the other makes us wet.
Altera ſegnes; alt ra reddit uvidos.
What? doth not wraſtling like you?

cell.hi: I am afraid of falling. or, breaking a limb.

row.cell: Have you not a mind to ride?

cell.hi: I never came on a horſes back.

row.cell: Have you not a mind to hunt?
We want nets, hunting poles and dogs.
Have you not a mind to ſwim?
It is an unprofitable and a dangerous skill, and whereof we have no leave given us.

cell.hi: Ars eſt inutilis & periculoſa, & nobis inconceſſa.

row.cell: Have you not a mind to ſhoot?
You ſhould have got it mended,
If I had mony enough I would buy me ſuch books as I want.
Si pecunia ſuppéteret, émerem libros, quibus opus eſt.

cell.hi: I would never give me my mind to it

row.cell: That's ſtrange, ſeeing it is both an ingenious thing, and very pleaſant.

cell.hi: Mirum, quum & liberále ſit, & perquám jucusdum.

row.cell: I beleive it. But I from a child could never abide to ſing.
Credo. Sed ego à pueritiâ ſemper abhorrui à canendo.
Now ſeeing no liberall exerciſe delighteth you I wonder that any body can endure to play with you.
Cum verò nulla te-liberalis exercit átio detectet, demiror ſi quis tecum ludere ſuſtineat.
O you mad boy, do you think that all are ſo teſty as you are?
O inſane, credis univerſo; tam tétricos eſſe quám tu et?
Indeed I would (play) if I could.
Hold your peace, the maſter is here: if he ſhould catch us talking, and ask us, what anſwer ſhould we make?
Tace, magiſter adeſt, ſi nos confabulantes deprehendat, & perconté ur quid reſpondeamus?

cell.hi: I can eaſily finde what to anſwer.

row.cell: Col. 20. Giles the Father, Frederick the Son.
What if he be not at home?
Give him it in the ſchool
That he would doe what the letters mention.

cell.hi: Ʋt id faciat quod iſtae loquuntur literae.

row.cell: Muſt I come againe quickly, after I have delivered them?
Jubes me ſtatim recurrere, poſtquam reddidi.
If your maſter thinke oo d.

cell.hi: Si praeceptóri tuo ſic viſum fúerit.

row.cell: What if he neither ſay I, nor nay?

Quid ſi ne
que ánnuat, ne
que renuat.
He will doe the one of the two Dve not fear it.
Ho, Ho, Hubert, the beſt of my companions.
I. You come to me in very good time.

cell.hi: What is the buſineſſe? tell me quickly.
I am going to fetch the maſter • h me.

row.cell: With whom did he goe thither?
I know not. You buſie your ſelfe about trifles.
Nihil ſcio. Nugae ſunt, quas agis.
Nay but, I deſire a ſerious peice of huſineſs of you.
Imó, abs te ſériam óperam éxpero.
I would not ſay nay to it if I had leiſure: but I am not at leiſure now.
Non a nuam, ſi vacet: ſed non vacat modò.
It will not be long. I pray thee, doe not go a way any whither.
Non eri: langum. Quaeſo, ne quo abeas.

cell.hi: What is your will; ſay in a word.

row.cell: That you would tell me the meaning of this letter.
Give it me, that I may quickly peruſe it.
Do you bid me to break open another mans letter?
Tu me jubes aliénas literas reſignáre?
It is not another mans. My father wrote it.

cell.hi: Non ſunt alienae. Pater meus ſcripſit.

row.cell: And he bade me carry it to my maſter.
Now I much fear me leſt this letter ſhould complain of me.
Nunc ego mihi malè métuo, ne me criminentur hae literae.
Why then do you ſay you fear, leſt it ſhould complaine of you?

cell.hi: Cur ergò timere te dicis, ne te criminentur?

row.cell: Becauſe my father ſaid it was a letter of commendations. Where I ſuſpect there is ſome trechecy under-hand.
Quoniam pater dicit eſſe commendatitias. Vhi ſuſpicor ſubeſſe fraudem.

cell.hi: You ſay that which is likely to be true.

row.cell: L • os upon the letter quickly, it will reſolve us of all the matter.
Inſpice literas cito. Illae nobis rem omnem expédient.
Herman Ceratine ſends commendations to Evaldus Gallus.

cell.hi: Hermánus Ceratinus Evaldo Gallo ſalútém dicit.

row.cell: He that delivereth you this letter is very tender to me, becauſe he is my ſon: I pray you ſtrive to mend him, leſt I begin to hate him for his naughtineſſe.
Qui tibi has tradit literas chariſſimus mihi eſt, quia filius: hunc, quaeſo ne proptey improbitatem odiſſe inciptam, emendáre ſtude.
Words, or rating, or chiding, will doe no good upon him.
Verbis nihil proficitur, aut increpatióne, aut jurgio.
Wherefore I intreat you that you would do the feare with tods.
Quare te deprecor, ut virgis rem péragas.
Take heed you hurt not his bones.
I can eaſily endure you to beate his skin and fleſh.

cell.hi: Pellem & carnem fácilè patior ut diverberes.

row.cell: This is Bellerophons letter (i. e. againſt ones ſelfe)
I ſhall not be ſo long.

cell.hi: Will not your maſter find that out.

row.cell: Not at all. He knoweth not my fathers hand.
But how will you change it?
If you will ſpeak it briefly.
Herman Ceratine ſends commendations to Evaldus Gallus.
Hermanus Ceratinus Evalda Gallo S. D. *
He that delivereth you this letter is moſt dear to me, becauſe he is my ſon: I pray you do not begin to diſlike him, for the naughtineſſe of others.

cell.hi: Qui tibi has tradit literas, chariſſimus mihi eſt quia filius: hunc, quaeſo ne propter aliórum fraudem odiſſe incipta • .

row.cell: If he ſhall do any thing amiſſe, labor to amend him with words.
Si quid peccabit, emendáre ſtude verbis.
One may doe much good upon him with blaming: and chiding.
VVherefore I intreat you that you would not do it with rods.

cell.hi: Quare te deprecor ut ne vergis rem peragas.

row.cell: I am ſo far off from having his bones to be hurt, that I cannot well abide his skin or fleſh to be beaten.
Oſſa tantum abeſt, ut ve lim laedi, ut ne fácile qúidem paetiar pellem illius, aut carnem diverberari.
Artificioſa, ita me dii bene ament, mutatio,
But take heed, that neither of them underſtand the knavery.
Sed cavè, ne reſciſcat uter vis eorum impoſturam.

cell.hi: I will have a care of theſe things.
you have held me too long.
Run ſo much the faſter now.

row.cell: Col. 21. Joyce a boy, Lydia a girle.

cell.hi: Will you tell me what I ask you?

row.cell: Vis mihi diee: e quod te interrogo?
If you ask me a wiſe queſtion.
Is the School-maſter at your houſe?
He is: he fits within by the fire-ſide.
What ſhould he do! He is drinking.
May not I goe to him?

cell.hi: An mihi non licet eum adire?

row.cell: I pray you, tell him, that I ſtand here at the door.
Obſecro te, ut annuncies illi, quod hîc adſtem prae foribus.

cell.hi: Whom ſhould I ſay you are?

row.cell: I will do ſo. Come in, tarry here a little, whileſt I goe to him.
Fae iam. Ingrédere, Opperitor hîc páu ulum, du mad illum adeo

cell.hi: Run and make haſt back againe as ſoone as may be.

row.cell: Col. 22. Michael the maſter, and Nychaſius the boy.
Do you enquire for me, Nych ſius?

cell.hi: A youth taries for you at home: if it be no trouble to you, he deſires to ſpeak with you.

row.cell: Adoleſcens quidam te expectat domi: ſi non eſt moleſtum, is te cupit convenire.

cell.hi: Cannot you reſolv me what he would with me?

row.cell: Non tu mihi potes expedire, quid nos velit?
N • . He hath ſomething under his clothes, which he brings you.
Minimè. Habet quid ſub veſte, quod affert tibi.
Run before, and tel him I will be with him preſently.
Col. 23. Orpheus, Phillip, the gueſts, Placida, the woman that keeps the tavern.
Col. 23, Orpheus, Philippus, Compotatóres, Plácida vinaeria.

cell.hi: We have ſat here long enough ſirs.

row.cell: Why doe we not call a reckoning preſently?
Even juſt now, if you pleaſe, we will not hinder you. Your buſineſs calls you away, and is earneſt.

cell.hi: J am nunc modó ſi tu ita vis, non tibi erimus in morá.

row.cell: You ſee your ſelves how many pintes you have drunk, and you know the rate of the wine.

cell.hi: Vidétis ipſi quot ſextários bibéritis, & pretium vini ſcitis.

row.cell: Now let us conſider how many you are in the company.
Do you it. That is a part of your office.
Tu facito. Tuum iſtud eſt officii.
There is no body gone away: as many as we came in at the beginning, ſo many are we here preſent.

cell.hi: Nemo diſceſſit. Quot intrávimus initio, tótidem hic ſumus praeſentes.

row.cell: Here are five men, and ſeven pintes: if every one pay three halfe pintes, you will have one half pint to come in: & truly I will fill you out this very neatly.
Cápita hic ſunt quinque, ſextarii ſeptem: ſi ſolvant ſinguli heminas ternas, accedet vobis cotyla una: hanc ego vobis convenienter admétiar.
Let us have the eight part of a pint, & make it up a whole pinte.

cell.hi: Accédat tuum acet • bulum, & fac uti ſextarius fiat.

row.cell: I do not refuſe, that you may come ſee us again another time.

cell.hi: Non recúſo, uti nos dênuo reviſátis aliâs.
Moſt merry comrades do you jovelize it here and fare you well.

row.cell: Contubernáles feſtiviſſimi vos hic vivite & valéte.

cell.hi: Stay till you drink once more.

row.cell: Truly I have drunk ofener then once, and that one draught will not make me merrier. Therefore my deareſt friends fare you wel.
Equidem ſaepius bibi quàm ſemel, nec ille me únius hauſtus faciet laetiorem, proinde vos valéte, chariſſima mihi cápita.
And you alſomoſt ſweet merry companion.
Col. 24. Richard a ſcholar, Strabo the maſter.
My father hath ſent you theſe ſmall fiſhes.
Fiſhes? Truly this is a rarity.
But I eſteem it as a very great preſent.
At mihi máximi muneri eſt inſtar.
My father intreats you that you would take it in good part.
You ſhall tell him it is as we come to me, as any thing can be.
Sic gratum eſſe renunciabis, ut gratius eſſe nihil poſſit.
Eſpecially at this time. For towards the evening (God willing) we expect two ſtrangers here.
Hoc praeſertim tempore. Siquidem in véſpera (Deo volente) duos convivas hic expectamus.
We wil make them merry with theſe fiſhes.
Eos his piſcicu' is exhilat ábimus.
Stay a little, ill I make the Basket be emptied for you.
Reſiſte pauliſper, dum tibi ſporiulam hanc evacuári jubeo.
Take your basket again childe, and thanke your father heartily from me.
Récipe ſportulam, mi fili, & age patri tuo máximas gratias meo nómine.
Intreat him over and above from me, that he would daign to come to me at ſix a clock, to partake of what he hath ſent.
Roga inſuper meis verbis, ut ad horam ſextam ad me venire dignetur, fruiturus iiſdem quos miſit.
There is no need you ſhould be at any charges for him.
Non eſt neceſſe, te fácere ullos ſumptus propter eum.
Seeing you will bave it ſo, I will doe it.
Col. 25. Titus a boy Vitus the maſter.
My miſtris would have him ſit down, if any body be hungry.
Jubet, hera ut accumbat, ſi quis éſurit.
We ſit down. Do you bring the meate in the meane time:
Nos accumbimus. Tu cibos affer intérea.
The Gammon of Bacon and the hang'd Beefe.
Two bunches of nettles. A pox take thee with the queſtion?
Urticae faſciculos duos. Dii te perdant cum iſtâ qiaeſtione!
Why doe you not ask her, who dreſt the meat?
Quin eam interroges, quae cibos coxit?
But ſhe badelme, that I ſhould ask you?
At illa me juſtit, ut rogitem te.
You have asked once; hereafter leave aſking.
Col. 26. Anthony the father, Beatus the Son.

cell.hi: Say grace for us boys what do you ſtick on?

row.cell: Conſecráte nobis menſam pueri, Ʋbi haeretis?
My brother is not at home, father.
He is not come again yet with the beer.
Do you ſay grace in the mean time.

cell.hi: I cannot ſay a grace yet by heart.

row.cell: When wil you learn one at laſt?
Be ſure you get one within this three dayes.
Truly I will do my utmoſt.
Col. 27. Chriſtian the Maſter, Dionyſe the boy.
What need is there of any ladders?
Why do you not aske rather for meat or drink?
Quin tu cibum petis, aut potum?
Leave trifling. I pray you, and ſpeak to the purpoſe,
Mitte nugári, quaeſo & dic rem ipſam.
I would know what is awanting here.

cell.hi: Me thinks I have miſſed nothing.

row.cell: I will make you ſee, what you doe not ſee.
Efficiam ut videas quod vides minus.
Do ſo I pray you, but without a jeer.
Tell me after what order you furniſh the Table.
Dic quo ordine menſam inſtru • s.
Firſt, I lay on the table cloth.
Then I ſay the Trenchers, or plates in order.
Every one hath his plate forſooth.
Then I ſet on the wreath with the Saltſeller.
I doe not diſallow of your faſhion in ordering.
After this I place the Houſhold bread.
For concerning the white bread you gave order apart.
Nam de pane triticeo ſeorſum dediſti mandátum.
Afterwards I waſh the Cups, and ſet them down empty as you bade.
Poſteà proluo pocula, & depono vácua, ſicut juſſiſti.
Laſt of all, when yee are ſet, the meate is brought; the Cups are filled. For every one of you ſets himſelfe a ſtool.

Poſtrémo quando acc •
buiſtis, affertur cibus; implenter pocula. Nam ſellam ſibi quiſque veſtrûm diſpónit.
Do you ſee none of thoſe things awanting here, which you have reckoned up?
Nihil hîc vides deeſſe eorum, quae recenſuiſti.
Bring hither a Trencher, and another Saltſeller too.
Could I tell beforehand. how many there would be at the Table?
An ego divináre póteram, quot eſſent futuri convivae?
What doe you ſtand here ſtill, you ruſſian-rogue.
Col. 28. Everard the Boy, Flaccus the Maſter.
Whence would you have me fetch it.

cell.hi: I heare it is good no where.

row.cell: What is it at the Star?
It is pure indeed, but thin

cell.hi: At the bottom of the Barrell.

row.cell: Is there none at the helmet?
That which he hath brewed, is not ſtale enough.
It hath not yet done working, you would have ſaid.
What do they ſell at the King?
What do they ſell at the budget?
To their friends beer, to others ſtale.
A pox take all the Brewers?
God bleſſe them rather, unleſſe you will drink water.
Dii ſervent potius, niſi vultis potáre aquam.
Why do they not brew good beer then?
Curetiam non coquant bonam cer viſiam?
If they wanted nothing. they would doe it.
Sometimes the Mault is weak, ſometimes they put in too much water, ſometimes they do not give it leave to work.
Aliàs eſt polenta lenis, aliàs affundunt plus ſatis aquae, aliàs non ſinunt deſervére.

cell.hi: You have hit the naile on the head.

row.cell: Goe where you will, but bring that which is pure good.
Vade quocunque vis, ſed affer ſinceram.

cell.hi: How much muſt I have again of it?

row.cell: I will doe it as I goe, when I have leiſure.

cell.hi: I will be here againe by and by.

row.cell: Have a care that you bring me back good money.
Ut mihi reportes bonam pecuniam, vide.

cell.hi: I will have as great a care, as I can.

row.cell: And I would have you uſe your eyes too. For your care is very little.
Et óculos volo, ut adhibeas. Nam cura tua perquám exigua eſt.
Col. 29. Gregory the boy, Hermes the maſter.
Much good may this Beer do you.
Fill us ſome, that we may try the worth of it.
Inſunde nobis, ut probemus quid váleat.
Reach yee every man his cup.
In very deed it is good
Col, 30. Joſſe the waiter, Lawrence the Maſter.
Theſe big bellied pots do not ſatisfie me.
Bid them bring us a bigger cup.
That you bring me hither two cups ſomewhat larger then theſe Gally-pots.
Ut mihi huc áfferas duo pocula paulo capaciora quàm hi cuculli.
It is done. Here they be.
Out upon you with, that idleneſſe!
Becauſe you offer us them ſo cleanly.
Truly I waſhed them for all that.
Would you have me beleeve you?
This foulneſſe cannot be waſh ed off with water.
Iſtae ſordes ablui non poſſunt aqua.
Bring them not againe, but very cleanly.
What if I break them, when I begin to ſcrape them?
Quid ſi frangam, ubi occepi rádere?
Looke to yourſelfe. For unleſſe the Cups remaine whole to day, your buttocks ſhall not remaine whole to morrow.
Tibi proſpices. Nam niſi pocula integra permanſerint hodiè, tuae nates integrae non permanébunt craſtinò.

cell.hi: Therefore take heed to your ſelfe.

row.cell: Col. 31. Melchior the waiter, Nichaſius the Maſter.
I deſire to be taught but without chiding.
VVhatſoever ſavours not of a jeſt is chiding to you.
Quicquid non ſapit jocum, tibi jurgium eſt.
Yet truly I will remember thoſe things which you commanded me.
Equidem illa, quae mihi praecepiſti, rectè mémini tamen.
I, the very ſame. Nor am I ſuch a blockhead, as you make me.
Nempe iſtud ipſum: Nec ſum tam hebes, quàm tu me facis.
It remains therefore that you learn what manners he muſt uſe, that is a waiter at a Table.
Supereſt igitur ut diſcas, quibus moribus utendum ſit illi, qui convivii miniſter eſt.
For in this matter there is much miſ-taking
Nam hdc in re multúm peccátur.
Firſt therefore I would have you remember this, that you are a ſervitor at the Feaſt.
Principio hoc volo ut memineris, miniſtrum te eſſe convivii.
And therefore think that you are not to layter after the gueſts are ſer.
Proinde cogita, non ceſſandum tibi, poſtquám accubuêre convivae.
But as I would not have you be ſlow, ſo I would not have you too haſty, remembring that Proverb, which you learned, when you were a novice.
Verum ut tardum eſſe te nolo, it a nolo eſſe praecipitem, ſed proverbii mémorem, quod, cum eſſes novitius, edidiciſti.

VVhat is that Proverb, I pray you? For amongſt ſo many things which I have learned, I can hardly gueſſe; unleſſe you meane this; make ſpeed leaſurely. i. e. No more haſt then good ſpeed; or, not too faſt.
Quid iſtud eſt, quaeſo, proverbium? naminter tam multa, quae didici, difficulter poſſum conjectare; niſi hoc vis; Feſtina lentè.
But that very ſame I will remember.

See therefore you ſtand mannerly at the table alwayes (but when you take any thing away, or ſet it on) not ſullen or pouting, but with a lively and cheerfull count enance, not with your eyes looking down upon the ground, nor faſtened upon any of the gueſts, but gently ready to move at every ones back, eſpecially at the Maſters of the feaſt; and then with a mouth not gaping, but with your lips lightly joyned together.

Fac igitur (niſi dum tollis quid, vel apponis) menſae reverentur aſſiſtas uſ
que non triſtis ac putidus, ſed vultu renidenti, ac hilari, non óculis humi dejectis, nec in quenquam convivárum defixis, ſed plácidè mobilibus ad omnes omnium nutus convivatoris; máxime tum ore néutiquam biante, ſed labris leviter conjunctis,
I will take order that I be blameleſſe as concerning the mouth, and eyes.
Efficiam ut ſim inculpatus, quantum ad os áttinet & oculos.
I will performe it indeed you ſhall ſee.
Neither take notice of it, if the gueſts ſpeak any thing inconſiderately; nor heed it, if they ſpeak any thing uncivily.
Nec, ſi quid à convivis dicitur inconſiderátius, adverte, nec ſi quid inurbánius, obſerva.
You forbide me the ſame lately.
For I would have you to be quite deaf to filthy talk.
Nam ad obſcoenos ſermones prorſus volo ſis ſurdus.

cell.hi: A thing which I have often told you of.

row.cell: Moreover, If any man would have any thing, ſupply him out of hand.
Porro, ſi quis quid vult, actutum ſuppédita.
Set away the empty diſhes, fill the cups againe, but not to the brim.
Evacuátos catinos ámove, pócula reple, ſed non ad ſummum labrum.
I will make them to be a little leſſe then full.
Paulo minus faxo fint quàm plena.
Take away the platters and ſet on others, and again look about you.
Forſooth, leſt I ſhould ſpill the pottoge upon any bodies clothes.
Vidélicit, ne cui veſtem jure perfundam.
So indeed. You ſhall neither taſte the meat aforehand, nor, if any dainty bit be left, ſhall you gobble it up.
Ita ſanè. Cibum neque praeguſtábis, neque ſi quid lautius ſuperfuerit, abliguries.
Peace I beſeech you: the Cook-maid hath untaught me that lately.
Tace, obſecro. Iſtud me nuper coqua dedocuit.
If the ſtrangers offer you any thing, refuſe it modeſtly; but if they preſſe it upon you, take it: and going aſide a little, you ſhall either eat it, or ſet it up.
Siquid à convivis offertur verecundè reculábis; ſin inſtiterint, recipies; & páululum digreſſus, vel comedes, vel ſepones.
The gueſts offer me meat ſeldome, but drink ever and anon.
Cibos raro, potum ſubindè, offerunt convivae.
If that be done at any time, drink a little and having filled the Cup againe, reſtore it.
Id ſi quando ſit, páululum bibet; & repléto poculo, dénuo reſtitue.
Will you not have mee waſh it?

cell.hi: It is not alwaies requiſite. See you he very ſparing of words.
Non eſt ſemper neceſſe. Verborum vide ut ſis parciſſimus.
If you be to anſwer any thing, ſpeak in ſhort; ſay nothing of your ſelfe without aſking.
Si quid reſpondendum fuerit, paucis oratiónem abſolve; ultrò verbum nullum proferas.

row.cell: Our Giles taught me of late to avoid babling; whom the ſtrangers (becauſe they ſaw him all tittle tattle,) ſet on a prating, and flouted him when he was gone aſide.
Multiloquium ut vitem, documento mihi nuper fuit Aegidius noſter; quem hoſpites (quoniam loquáculum eſſe perſpéxerant) ad garriendum provocâre; digreſſum perſtringébant.

cell.hi: When any body ſends you any whither upon an errant, do not goe away, unleſſe you firſt underſtand what is your errant.
Miſſus à quoquam ad conficiendum negótium, abire noli, ni priùs intellexer is quid ſit imperátum.

row.cell: VVhat If I aske one again when I have not well underſtood him?
Quid ſi denuo rogitem, cum intellexi minus?
You ſhould offend leſſe, if you enquire twice, then if you doe your errant the wrong way.
Minus peccábis ſi bis quaeras, quàm ſi perverſe negótium conficias.
VVhat remains after ſo many inſtructions?
That you be free from filth all over your body, but eſpccially on your face and hands.
Ur ſórdibus vaces toto quidem corpore, ſed máximè fácie & manibus.
I will make my ſelfe a pretty neat, and hanſome little fellow.
Scarce any where elſe but here truly.
I pray you tell me, doe you practiſe any trade • ere?
Dic ſodes, ecquam hic èx erces artem?
I doe not underſtand what trade that ſhould be.
I ſweep my Maſters Houſe and chamber.
I make the bed, I make the fire, I fetch water, I waite upon my Maſter, forth and home againe.

cell.hi: Concinno lectum, ſtruo ignem, apporto aquam, abdúco herum, & redùco.

row.cell: Waiting on my maſter whileſt he is at dinner, I reade over a chapter in the Bible.
When do you dine your ſelfe?
When he hath got his dinner.
What doe you uſe to eat?

cell.hi: How can you lay up ſo much meate in one belly?
Quomodo pote tantum cibi cóndere in unam alvum?

row.cell: Nay rather I take what ſerves my turn of what I have a minde to?
Imo de quocunque lubet, ſumo quantum ſatis eſt.
Who ſpends the other that is left?

cell.hi: They are beſtowed upon the poore.

row.cell: The Gammons of Bacon too, and the powdered meate.
He hath none of theſe things in his houſe.
Nihil horum habet in aedibus ſuis.
What doe you live on then? or what is your daily ſuſtenance?
Ʋnde vivitis autem? Quaeve ſunt quotidiána alimenta?
Who gets his meate ready for him?
What do you thinke of me?
I know not what you are now. Once verily thou waſt as dull as a Beetle.
Quales nunc ſis, neſcio. Olim certè non fuit quicquam hebetius.
This man hath ſharpened me and informed me?
Yes. But on this condition, that I ſhould never leave him.
Omnino. Sed hac lege, ut ab illo nunquam diſcédam.
Art thou ſuch a foole, that thou wouldſt yeeld thy ſelf perpetually to ſerve any man for no reward?
Adeóne ſtulius es, ut alicui te in pérpetuam ſervitútem tradas nullo praemio?
Can you deſire any greater reward then I have?
Ecquid magis praemium expetas, quám ego fero?
Tell me, what reward doe you receive.
He will give me my meate and drinke as long as I live.
Quoad vivam, ſuppeditábit hic mihi alimoniam.
Do you ſerve for meat and drink onely? where is your apparell in the meane time?
Tune ſervis pro alimonia tantum? ubi veſtitus interim?
He allowes me ſuch clothes as you ſee.
